(Ord. No. 12-002, § 2, 6-19-12) Sec. 14-87. - Compliance effective dates. (a) (1) Any dog classified prior to July 1, 2012, as a potentially dangerous dog in under this article or in this state shall on and after that date be classified as a dangerous dog under this article. (2) Any dog classified prior to July 1, 2012, as a dangerous dog or vicious dog under this article or in this state shall on and after that date be classified as a vicious dog under this article. (b) The owner of any dog referred to in subsection (a) above shall come into compliance with all current provisions of this article by January 1, 2013. (Ord. No. 12-002, § 2, 6-19-12) Secs. 14-88—14-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-002, § 2, adopted June 19, 2012, repealed art. IV, §§ 14-101—14-108, which pertained to vicious animals and derived from Amend. of 4-5-05, § 1(4.1)—(4.8).
Secs. 14-101—14-108. Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING CONSTRUCTION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— A resolution adopted April 7, 2015, repealed Ch. 18, §§ 18-1—18-103, which pertained to buildings and building construction and derived from Ord. of 11-21-95; Ord. of 4-16-96; Res. of 5-21-96; Res. of 4-6-99; Res. of 8-3-99(1); Amend. of 1-16-01; Ord. of 12-18-01(2); Ord. of 12-18-01(4); Ord. of 2-5-02, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 11-15-05. Subsequently, an ordinance adopted Sept. 5, 2017 re-adopted Ch. 18, Art. I, §§ 18-1, Art. II, §§ 18-31—18-35, Art. III, §§ 18-56—18-59, and Art. IV, §§ 18-101—18-103, as set out herein. These provisions were previously repealed by the adoption of the Unified Development Code of Catoosa County, Georgia, Resolution of 4-7-2015, as adopted by the Board of Commissioners on April 7, 2015. Original history notes to said sections have been restored to preserve historical reference. Cross reference— Development Authority of Catoosa County, § 2-151 et seq.; United Development Code, app. A.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Self-inspection by plumbers, utility contractors. The county is exempted from the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d) relating to the self-inspection of certain water and sewer lines, and such provisions shall not be applicable in the county. (Res. of 5-21-96; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Secs. 18-2—18-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES
Sec. 18-31. - Adopted. The following codes, the latest editions, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, are hereby adopted by reference and shall be enforced within the county: (1) State adopted Building Code including: All appendices. (2) State adopted Mechanical Code including: All appendices. (3) State adopted Gas Code including: All appendices. (4) State adopted Plumbing Code including: All appendices. (5) State adopted Electrical Code including: All appendices. (6) State adopted Fire Prevention Code including: Chapter 1, all appendices. (7) State adopted One- and Two-Family Dwelling Code including: All appendices. (8) State adopted Energy Code for Buildings including: All appendices. (9) State adopted Unsafe Building Abatement Code. (10) State adopted Swimming Pool Code. (11) State adopted Existing Building Code including: Chapter 1, appendix A. (12) State adopted Amusement Device Code. (13) State adopted Housing Code. (Ord. of 11-21-95; Ord. of 4-16-96; Amend. of 1-16-01; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) State Law reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶¶ I, III(a)(12); construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25. Sec. 18-32. - Administration and enforcement. The county building inspector shall enforce the provisions of this article and the codes adopted herein as provided in attachment A to the ordinance from which this article was derived, which attachment is hereby saved from repeal. (Ord. of 11-21-95; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-33. - Permit fees. The schedule for permit fees applicable under this article shall be as set forth in attachment B to the ordinance from which this article is derived and shall be maintained in the office of the building official in accordance with attachment B. (Ord. of 11-21-95; Amend. of 1-16-01; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-34. - Amendments. (a) The provisions of the National Electrical Code, Standard Fire Prevention Code, CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code and the Standard Building Code which provide for the use of electrical wire smaller than number 12 A.W.G. copper are deleted in their entirety. (b) From and after the date of the adoption of this section, the minimum electrical carrying wire shall be number 12 A.W.G. copper except that on the switch leg number 14 A.W.G. wire may be used. (c) The provisions regarding minimum electrical carrying wire contained in all building codes enforced in the county in conflict with this section are repealed. (Res. of 4-6-99; Res. of 8-3-99(1); Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-35. - Installation of gas pipe. The installation of gas piping shall be regulated by the building inspection department. Gas piping shall be authorized to be installed under the HVAC or plumbers license issued by the State of Georgia. The venting of gas appliances is currently authorized under the HVAC license issued by the State of Georgia only, and shall remain as such. All other exceptions, rules, and orders established by the Georgia Construction Industry Licensing Board shall apply. This section shall in no way circumvent the established laws and rules set forth by the Georgia Construction Industry Licensing Board for medical gas and medical gas piping systems. (Amend. of 1-16-01; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Secs. 18-36—18-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SWIMMING POOLS, SPAS, AND RECREATIONAL WATER PARKS RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 18-56. - Rules and regulations. The [State of] Georgia, Department of Human Resources has adopted rules and regulations entitled and published as "Swimming Pools, Spas, and Recreational Water Parks Chapter 290-5-57." The swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks rules and regulations do not provide for enforcement by making a violation thereof a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine or imprisonment, or both. The board of commissioners has determined that it is necessary and desirable to establish a procedure for enforcement of the swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks, rules and regulations by making a violation of the swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks rules and regulations a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 per violation, per day, or 30 days imprisonment, or both, and establishing enforcement provisions. (Ord. of 12-18-01(2); Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-57. - Adoption of ordinance. The rules and regulations of the [State of] Georgia, Department of Human Resources entitled and published as "Swimming Pools, Spas, and Recreational Water Parks, Chapter 290-5-57" are hereby adopted as written, in revised form, as of the date of this article, and as amended from time to time, as the swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks ordinance of the county. A copy of the swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks rules and regulations are attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference. (Ord. of 12-18-01(2), § I; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-58. - Enforcement. Prosecutions for violations of the county swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks ordinance shall be upon citation as provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-62 and 15-10-63, as amended. The officers of the county health department, environmental section, are hereby authorized to issue citations for the enforcement of the provisions of the county swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks ordinance in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63, as amended. (Ord. of 12-18-01(2), § II; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-59. - Penalty. Any person violating a provision of the county swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 per violation, per day, or 30 days imprisonment, or both; and if such violation be continued, each day upon which a violation occurs shall be considered a separate offense. Violation of this article may also be enforced by the seeking of civil remedies against the violator. (Ord. of 12-18-01(2), § III; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Secs. 18-60—18-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR THE USE OF CERTAIN COUNTY BUILDINGS
Sec. 18-101. - Intent. The county owns several buildings which are under the control and jurisdiction of the board of commissioners of the county. These buildings include the buildings located at the Benton Place Campus, the voting precinct buildings located throughout the county, the Nutrition Center located in the City of Ringgold, Constitution Hall located in Fort Oglethorpe, and gymnasiums which are attached to certain voting precinct buildings. During the time that some of these buildings are not used for a governmental purpose, it has been policy of the board of commissioners to allow private citizens, civic groups, churches, clubs, youth groups, senior citizens, and other associations to use some of the buildings. All of these buildings are maintained with county funds and the board of commissioners believes that they should be utilized to the fullest extent possible consistent with the primary governmental purposes for which the buildings were constructed. The board of commissioners finds that it is in the best interest of the county and the taxpayers of the county that certain user groups pay a fee to help pay for the maintenance of the buildings. The use of certain of the buildings has been dedicated to specific purposes and the management of certain buildings has been delegated to certain non-profit groups or the county has entered into contracts with the department of community affairs and others which restrict the use of some of the buildings. The board desires by this article to provide for a written policy regarding the use of the buildings, the fees which will be charged to use the buildings, the conditions in which the buildings can be used, and rules for the use of the buildings. (Ord. of 12-18-01(4); Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-102. - Open use buildings. (a) [Applicability of section.] This subsection shall apply to the following: The voting precinct buildings located in the City of Ringgold, (the Courthouse Annex), the Boynton Voting Precinct Building, the Westside Voting Precinct Building, the Lakeview Voting Precinct Building, the Chambers Voting Precinct Building, the Blackstock Voting Precinct Building, and the Keith Voting Precinct Building, the voting precinct portion of the Graysville Precinct and Gymnasium building, the voting precinct portion of the Woodstation Precinct and Gymnasium building and the Elsie Holmes Park Screened Building. (b) [Public use.] So long as the open use buildings are not needed for a governmental purpose, the general public shall have the right to use the buildings. The public use of the open use buildings shall be generally provided on a first come and pay, first serve basis. The office of the board of commissioners shall maintain a list of the individuals through who each of the open use buildings can be reserved. The open use buildings may be used by the general public for civic club meetings, religious services, meetings and organization purposes, veteran meetings, senior citizen meetings, recreational association meetings, private receptions, weddings, private parties, dances, or any other non-profit, nonmoney-making purpose, subject to the conditions contained this article. The open use buildings may not be used by a group or association which exposes racial ethnic or religious hatred or violence when the advocacy of such positions in the open use buildings might reasonably result in violence or civil disturbance in the judgment of the county official in charge of the open use building or the board of commissioners. The governmental use of the open use buildings shall have first priority even if the governmental need for the building arises after an open use building is reserved. (c) Fee. (1) Daily use. The open use buildings may be reserved for use at one or more event periods by the general public and organizations. Each event period includes clean-up time. The event period times are as follows: Event period 1: 6:30 a.m.—12:30 p.m.; Event period 2: 12:30 p.m.—6:30 p.m.; Event period 3: 6:30 p.m.—12:30 a.m. If the reservation is for a Catoosa County nonprofit corporation having 501(c)(3) status, there shall be no fee for the use of the open use building. The fee shall also be waived for Catoosa County nonprofit organizations or associations that have no paid employees in the local chapter. For all other user groups, the fee for using the open use buildings shall be $25.00 per event reservation is made. Reservations shall be made on first paid basis (or first deposit paid if no fee is required). A building is not reserved until the fee is paid and deposit is paid. A "key" and clean-up deposit of $50.00 shall be paid in advance by all users. The deposit shall be refunded if the key is returned and the building is cleaned to its condition before the use after the use. The fee and deposit will be refunded if the building is required to be used for a governmental function after the time that it is reserved and the fee and deposit is paid. (2) Long-term event reservation. The open use buildings may be reserved for one or more event periods at a specified time each week. Long-term reservation of event periods is limited to Monday through Thursday. The open use building may be reserved for one or more event periods each week for a period not to exceed 90 days. Thereafter the long-term use reservation must be renewed. The fee shall be paid for each event period reserved in advance. The user shall be required to pay a single deposit, which shall remain for the entire use unless the user fails to clean up after each event. If the user fails to clean up after an event, the deposit shall be applied to the clean-up and the long-term user shall be required to resecure the cleanup and key by making another $50.00 deposit. Long-term use reservation is not allowed Friday through Sunday. (3) Use by nonresident citizens. The open use buildings may be rented to nonresidents provided that the fee provided for the use of the open use building shall be paid by each nonresident irrespective of nonprofit status. The deposit shall also be required as provided above. (d) Exemptions from fee: The following user groups shall not be required to pay the fee: Nonprofit public purpose civic groups (Rotary, Kiwanis, etc.) religious groups, veterans' organizations, senior groups (AARP) and recreational associations, education groups, including, but not by way of limitation, home school groups who use the building as a part of their home school courses. Subject to subparagraph (a) above, these groups may reserve an open use building at a specific time each week provided that the user actually occupies the open use building each week. (e) Prohibitions: No user may charge admission to any of the open use buildings. Profit or money-making activities are prohibited in the open use buildings. Sales or promotions in connection with the use of open use buildings are prohibited. (f) Rules for use of open use buildings: The following rules shall apply to all users of the open use buildings. (1) A contract must be executed by the person reserving the open use building at the time the reservation is made and the fee is paid. The contract will have attached a copy of the rules for the use of the open use building and the individual executing the contract shall be personally responsible for complying with the rules and any damage to the open use building. (2) No hanging decorations will be allowed in the open use buildings. (3) No money making activities or any kind of admission fee will be permitted in the open use building. (4) No cleated shoes of any kind will be allowed in the open use buildings. (5) No signs or other materials will be taped to the front door or on the walls of the open use buildings. (6) The open use building must be vacated by 12:00 midnight. (7) The user groups may move and set-up the tables and chairs in the open use building in any manner that the user sees fit. The tables and chairs must be returned to the place where they were located and stored at the conclusion of the use. (8) Dragging chairs or tables across the floor is prohibited. (9) At the conclusion of the use of the building, the user shall inspect the building and make sure that all commodes are flushed and that all lights are turned off in the bathrooms. (10) At the conclusion of the use of the open use building the heating and air shall be set as follows: During winter use at the time the building is vacated turn the thermostat down to 50 degrees. Do not turn off the heat during the winter. During the time that the air conditioner is in use, it is to be turned off at the conclusion of the use. (11) All water faucets are turned off. (12) The building shall be cleaned and mopped at the conclusion of each use. Use a clean mop and dust mop when cleaning the floor. (13) Alcoholic beverages are not allowed in the buildings. (14) The user will be required to bring garbage bags to your event and to remove the garbage when the user leaves. (15) The user is required to lock all doors and turn off all lights inside and outside the buildings at the conclusion of the use. (16) Any user failing to comply with these rules shall be subject to any damages occasioned by the failure to follow these rules. (Ord. of 12-18-01(4), § I; Ord. of 2-5-02, § 1, 2; Ord. of 11-15-05; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Sec. 18-103. - Restricted use buildings. (a) This section shall apply to the following county buildings: The Catoosa County Courthouse Courtrooms, the Nutrition Center, the Colonnade, the Catoosa County Library, Constitution Hall, the gymnasiums attached to certain voting precinct buildings, the Health Department, the Senior Citizens Building at Benton Place, the Shirley Smith Literacy Center and the Board Room of the Catoosa County Courthouse. The use of these buildings is restricted and the general public is now allowed to use these buildings except as provided in this article. (b) Constitution Hall in Fort Oglethorpe: The Constitution Hall may be used by the general public and civic groups as regulated by the City of Fort Oglethorpe. Reserved through the City of Fort Oglethorpe in accordance with its rules: (c) The gymnasiums attached to the Graysville voting precinct building and Woodstation voting precinct buildings: These buildings are reserved for recreational use. These buildings are reserved through the Catoosa County recreation department. (d) The Shirley Smith Literacy Center: This building is reserved for educational purposes only and as determined by the Catoosa County Literacy Center, Inc. (e) The Colonnade: The use of the colonnade shall be as provided by the Catoosa Foundation for the Performing Arts; (f) The Catoosa County Courthouse courtrooms: The courtrooms are restricted to the uses permitted by the Judges of the Superior Court, the Judges of the Magistrate Court, the Judges of the Juvenile Court and the Judge of the Probate Court. The rooms are reserved by the Clerk of the Superior Court of Catoosa County, Georgia; (g) Senior Citizen Center: Use of this building is restricted by contract between Catoosa County and the Georgia Department of Community Affairs. This building can only be used as a senior citizens activity building; (h) Catoosa County Library: The Catoosa County Library use is managed by the Catoosa County Library Board. It may be used in accordance with the rules and regulations of the library board. (i) Nutrition Center: The nutrition center is a special use building, but at certain times it may be used as an open use building subject to the same rules applicable to the open use buildings. (Ord. of 12-18-01(4), § II; Ord. of 9-5-17(1) § 1) Secs. 18-104—18-120. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - UNFIT BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES
Sec. 18-121. - Ordinance remedial. This article is hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interest and purposes thereof—which are public safety, health and general welfare—through structural strength, stability, sanitation, adequate light, ventilation, hazard abatement and safety to life and property from fire, injury and other hazards incident to the construction, alteration, demolition, use and occupancy of dwellings, buildings and occupancy of dwellings, buildings or structures. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-122. - Definitions. (a) The term "applicable codes" means: (1) Any optional housing or abatement standard provided in O.C.G.A. Chapter 2 of Title 8, as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or other property maintenance standards as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or general nuisance law, relative to the safe use of real property; (2) Any fire or life safety code as provided for in O.C.G.A. Chapter 2 of Title 25; and (3) The minimum standard codes provided in O.C.G.A. Chapter 2 of Title 8, provided that such building or minimum standard codes for real property improvements shall be deemed to mean those building or minimum standard codes in existence at the time such real property improvements were constructed unless otherwise provided by law. (b) The term "closing" or "closure" means causing a dwelling, building or other structure to be vacated and secured against entry. (c) The term "county" means the unincorporated area of Catoosa County, Georgia. (d) The term "drug crime" means any act which is in violation of O.C.G.A. Article 2 of Chapter 13 of Title 16, known as the "Georgia Controlled Substances Act". (e) The term "dwellings, buildings, or structures" shall mean any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial or business uses, or intended to be so used and includes any outhouses, improvements and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. The term also includes manufactured housing, single wide mobile homes, double wide mobile homes, travel trailers, tents or temporary structures of every description. As used in this article and as used in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7, and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-9 through 41-2-17, the term "dwellings, buildings or structures" shall not mean or include any farm, or any building or structure located on a farm, or any agricultural facility or other building or structure used for the production, growing, raising, harvesting, storage or processing of crops, livestock, poultry or other farm products. (f) The term "governing authority" shall mean the board of commissioners of Catoosa County, Georgia. (g) The term "owner" shall mean the holder in title in fee simple and each and every security deed holder, lien holder or mortgagee of record. (h) The term "parties in interest" with respect to the property or premises in question means: (1) persons in possession of the property and premises; (2) persons having on record in the county, any vested right, title or interest in or lien upon such dwelling, building, or structure or the lot, tract, or parcel of real property upon which the dwelling, building or structure is situated or upon which the public health hazard or general nuisance exists based upon a 50-year title examination conducted in accordance with the title standards of the State Bar of Georgia; (3) persons having paid an occupational tax to the governing authority for the location or office of the subject building or structure; or (4) persons having filed a property tax return with the governing authority as to the subject property, dwelling, building or structure. (i) The term "public authority" means any member of the governing authority, any building code enforcement officer, any zoning officer, any member of the planning commission or any other officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the county government or the state government related to fire, health or building regulations or to other activities concerning dwellings, buildings or structures within the county. (j) The term "public officer" means the officer or officers who are authorized under this article to exercise the powers prescribed in this article and also includes any agent of such officer or officers. (k) The term "repair" means altering or improving a dwelling, building or structure so as to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes in the county and the cleaning or removal of debris, trash, or other material present and accumulated which create a health, fire or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building or structure. (l) The term "resident" means any person residing in the jurisdiction where the property is located on or after the date on which the alleged nuisance arose. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-123. - Duty of owner. It is hereby declared that it is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure or property within the unincorporated county to construct and maintain such dwelling, building, structure or property in conformance with the applicable codes enforced within the county, and such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on such property, and ordinances or laws which declare it to be a public nuisance to construct or maintain any dwelling, building, structure, or property in violation of such laws, codes or ordinances. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-124. - Designation of public officer. The zoning administrator is hereby designated and appointed to exercise the duties of the public officer prescribed in this article. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-125. - Investigation and complaint by county in rem. Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority or by in writing at least five residents of the county charging that any dwelling, building, structure or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; or is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crime; or which constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions; or has defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; or which lacks adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; or other conditions exist rendering such dwellings, buildings or structures unsafe or unsanitary or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or general welfare of the people; or which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation the public officer shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific dwelling, building, structure or property. If the public officer's investigation or inspection identifies that any dwelling, building, structure or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; or is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crime; or which constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions; or has defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; or which lacks adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; or other conditions exist rendering such dwellings, buildings or structures unsafe or unsanitary or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or general welfare of the people; or which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation, the public officer may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property upon which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served (as provided in section 18-133 hereof) on the owner and parties in interest in such dwelling, building or structure. The complaint shall identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; identify the owners and the parties in interest; state with particularity the factual basis for the action; and contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the health hazard and alleged nuisance. The summons shall notify the owner and parties in interest that a hearing will be held before the magistrate court of Catoosa County, Georgia at a date and time certain. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in the magistrate court. The owner and parties in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for the hearing. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-126. - Determination by the magistrate court. If, after such notice and hearing, the magistrate court determines that the dwelling, building, or structure in question is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; or is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of a drug crime; or which constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions; or has defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; or which lacks adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; or other conditions exist rendering such dwellings, buildings or structures unsafe or unsanitary or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or general welfare of the people; or which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner and any parties in interest that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: (a) If the repair, alteration or improvement of said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure, requiring the owner during the time specified in the order to repair, alter or improve such dwelling, building or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or (b) Tf the repair, alteration or improvement of said dwelling, building or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building or structure and all debris from the property. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-127. - Determination of reasonable cost. For purposes of this article, the court shall make its determination of "reasonable costs in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or other structure" without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that the costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve the structure may be considered. The income and financial status of the owner shall not be a factor in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the cost of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a Georgia appraiser classification as provided in O.C.G.A. Chapter 39a of Title 43, qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation in force in the jurisdiction. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-128. - Failure of the owner to comply with order. If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. If the dwelling, building or structure is closed, the public officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling or structure a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered to be secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-129. - Demolition. If the court orders the dwelling, building or structure to be demolished and the public officer is required to perform the demolition, reasonable efforts shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any money received from the sale of salvage materials shall be used or applied against the costs of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing the application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvage materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid on such terms and conditions as the public officer deems reasonable under the circumstances. The public officer may contract with a third party for the demolition of the dwelling building or structure if he/she determines it is in the best interest of the county to do so. The public officer and governing authority are relieved of any and all liability from or occasion by the sale of such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials. After completion of the repair or demolition the public officer shall prepare and certify a final statement of costs. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-130. - Lien for costs. The amount of the costs of demolition, including all contractors, equipment, labor, court costs, appraisal fees, attorney fees incurred by the public officer, as well as administrative costs incurred by the tax commissioner and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to the grade of the real property after demolition shall be a lien against the real property upon which costs was incurred. The lien provided herein shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring the repair, closure or demolition in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Catoosa County, Georgia and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under subsection (g) of O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12. The clerk of the superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. After filing a certified copy of the order with the clerk of the superior court, the public officer shall forward a copy of the order and the final statement of costs to the county tax commissioner. It shall the duty of the tax commissioner to collect the amount of the lien in connection with the collection of ad valorem taxes on the property and to collect the amount of the lien as if it were a real property ad valorem tax, using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes, including O.C.G.A. Chapter 4 of Title 48; provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. The tax commissioner shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the county. Thirty days after the imposition of the lien, the unpaid lien shall bear interest and penalties in the amount applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-131. - Waiver and release of lien. The board may waive and release any lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the county agreeing to a time table for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-132. - Ordinance not exclusive. Nothing contained herein shall limit the right of public officers to issue citations for violation of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety and other codes heretofore adopted by ordinance for enforcement, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and seeking to enforce such citations in accord of competent jurisdiction but prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this article. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A) Sec. 18-133. - Service of complaints or orders upon parties in interest and owners of unfit buildings or structures. The service of complaints and order issued by a public officer pursuant to this article shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12, which is by referenced incorporated herein. (Res. of 6-18-02; Ord. of 9-5-17(1), Exh. A)

div.head: Chapter 19 - BUSINESSES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 19-1—19-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TIMBER OPERATIONS
Sec. 19-31. - Purpose and intent. The purpose of this article is to provide procedures, rules and regulations governing persons, businesses and other entities engaged in timber cutting operations in Catoosa County and to provide for the issuance of permits to such operators in order to protect the health, welfare and safety of the citizens and the environment of the county, and in order to ensure the efficient operation and development of the county road system and to assure the public safety. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § II) Sec. 19-32. - Definitions. As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: Board means the Board of Commissioners of Catoosa County, Georgia, or their successors in office, being the governing authority of Catoosa County, Georgia. County means Catoosa County, Georgia. County road means any road located within the unincorporated area of Catoosa County, Georgia, over which the board exercises control and jurisdiction. Public property means any property owned, either in fee simple or otherwise titled, or held by the county, including, but not limited to, ditches, bridges and rights-of-way. Surety bond means one of the following: (1) Cash. (2) An irrevocable letter of credit. (3) A bond issued by a licensed surety authorized to transact business in the State of Georgia (and who is also listed on treasury circular 570 at the time of the filing). (4) Some other security or collateral acceptable to the county in the amount of $50,000.00. Timber means soft wood or hard wood trees and soft wood or hard wood logs. Timber harvester means any person, firm, business, company, corporation or other entity engaged in buying, selling, cutting or harvesting timber in Catoosa County for commercial purposes or for profit. Timber operations means buying, cutting, harvesting and/or hauling timber in Catoosa County, Georgia. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § III) Sec. 19-33. - Surety bond. (a) On or after January 1, 1998, no timber harvester shall engage in timber operations upon a county road or public property without first submitting a surety bond acceptable to the county in the amount of $50,000.00 to ensure the timber operator's compliance with the requirements of this article. The surety bond shall be issued to the county for a period of one year or until timber operations are complete and the county has inspected all county roads and public property used in connection with the timber operations. The surety bond shall name the county as obligee, shall be issued to the county and shall be posted with the department head of the county road department by an operator prior to the date of the commencement of timber operations. Each surety bond must contain a provision which allows the county to consent to the release and/or cancellation of the surety bond posted pursuant to this article. (b) The surety bond shall run to the county and provide that the timber harvester and the timber harvester's successors and assigns will: (1) Indemnify the county against any and all damage caused to county roads or public property as a result of timber operations; (2) Indemnify the county for costs incurred in the clean up of waste or debris left upon a county road or public property as a result of timber operations; and (3) Indemnify the county for any expenses incurred by the county through the failure of the timber harvester to complete any necessary repairs to county roads or public property in accordance with applicable standards acceptable to the county. (c) In the event a timber harvester damages county roads or public property while conducting timber operations on county roads or public property, then on any subsequent application for a permit pursuant to section 19-34 of this article the county may require a surety bond acceptable to the county in the amount of $75,000.00 to be posted by such timber harvester. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § IV) Sec. 19-34. - Permit. (a) No timber harvester shall engage in timber operations on a county road or public property without first securing a permit to conduct such operations in the county. A permit is required for each timber contract entered into by a timber harvester. (b) As a condition precedent to the issuance of a permit, the timber harvester must have submitted an acceptable surety bond to the county in accordance with section 19-33 of this article. (c) An application for a permit shall be submitted to the county in such manner and on such forms as the county prescribes and shall be accompanied by an application fee prescribed by the county. (d) Any timber harvester seeking a permit shall provide the following information for each permit requested: (1) The name and address of the owner of the property on which the timber harvester will engage in timber operations. (2) The location of the property upon which the timber harvester will engage in timber operations. (3) The county roads upon which the trucks used in connection shall travel. (4) The date timber operations are expected to commence and the estimated time of completion. (5) The names and addresses of all persons in a supervisory capacity engaged in timber operations at the location for which the permit is requested. (6) Identify all points of ingress and egress onto any county road which may be employed by the timber harvester. (7) If a timber harvester intends to engage independent contractors to haul the timber, the name and address of each independent contractor. (e) All applicants for a permit must submit evidence of financial responsibility. The county may require all applicants to provide financial statements and other evidence of financial responsibility in conjunction with the application. (f) A permit shall be valid for a period to be determined by the county. Such period shall not exceed the estimated time of completion of the specific timber operations identified in the permit, except that upon a showing of good cause, the county may grant an extension. (g) In the event the county denies an application for a permit, it shall send written notice of such denial to the applicant setting forth in the notice to reason for the action. Such notice shall state that it shall become final unless a written request for hearing is filed with the county within 15 days from the date of such notice, and the notice shall be delivered to the applicant either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested. The permit holder shall be entitled at such hearing to present such evidence and to cross-examine witnesses. Decisions of the county may be appealed to the superior court of the county by filing a written notice of appeal within 30 days of the county's decision. (h) Prior to the issuance of a permit, the department head of the county road department or his duly authorized representative will inspect the site to determine if a culvert is required along the county right-of-way and the size and length of the culvert, if any be required. If it is determined that a culvert is needed, it must be installed by the timber harvester under the supervision of the county road department. When the representative of the county road department makes the initial inspection of the site, the existing condition of any public property to be used by the timber harvester shall be documented. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § V) Sec. 19-35. - Duties of permit holder. (a) It shall be unlawful to engage in any timber operation except in such a manner as to conform to and to comply with all applicable requirements of this article. (b) It shall be the duty and responsibility of timber harvesters to control the activities of any subcontractors employed by the timber harvesters to prevent damage to county roads and public property and insure compliance with the requirements of this article. (c) No timber harvester shall allow dirt, mud or other debris resulting from timber operations to accumulate upon the right-of-way of any county road to such an extent that it becomes a nuisance or hazard to persons traveling upon such roads, or that it creates an unsightly condition upon public property. (d) No timber harvesters shall allow dirt, mud or other debris resulting from timber operations to accumulate in ditches and drainage areas on public rights-of-way to such an extent that the usual flow of water or run-off is stopped, disturbed, changed or interrupted. (e) No equipment, trucks or trailers which are used in connection with timber operations shall be left unattended or parked on any county road or right-of-way or public property. (f) Timber harvesters shall not damage county roads or public property while conducting timber operations. Timber harvesters shall take appropriate action to insure that all trucks hauling timber do not exceed applicable load limits for county roads being used by the timber harvester. (g) No timber harvester shall commence timber operations or continue said operations without first installing and maintaining a temporary drive cut and culvert to access the property and installing and maintaining soil erosion and sedimentation control sufficient to prevent dirt, mud and other debris from accumulating in the county drainage ditches upon public property, and upon the county roads upon which the timber harvester uses for the purposes of ingress and egress. (h) The timber harvester shall display a minimum of four warning signs, two in each direction of the road entrance to the timber operation. Two signs, one in each direction, shall be located 500 feet in each direction from the operation entrance and shall contain the following information: "Slow Truck Entering Highway." Two signs, one in each direction, shall be located 1,000 feet in each direction from the operation entrance and shall contain the following information: "Warning: Logging Operation Ahead." Each sign shall be 36 inches by 36 inches, orange in color, and shall be posted at least three feet from the travel surface of the applicable roadway. (i) All timber operations shall be conducted at a loading site off the county right-of-way and behind the established ditch line of county roads. (j) Loading or skidding of logs is not to be permitted on county roads. (k) That portion of county roads which are located at the timber operations entrance shall be kept serviceable at all times for the passing public, emergency vehicles, school buses, mail carriers, etc. (l) Timber harvesters shall use crushed stone or some other material, if necessary, on access roads to prevent the transporting of excessive amounts of mud, dirt, or other debris from the timber operations area onto the county right-of-way, county roads, or public property. (m) The timber harvester shall maintain and insure that the county roads and public property are returned to a state at least equal to that existing immediately prior to the instituting of the timber operations. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § VI) Sec. 19-36. - Administration. (a) Timber harvesters shall give the county written notice within 72 hours of the completion of timber operations. Within five days of said notice the county shall inspect the county roads and public property being used by the timber harvesters to determine if the same has been returned to a state at least equal to that existing immediately prior to the institution of timber operations. If it is determined by the county that the county roads and public property used by the timber harvester are not in a proper state of condition, the county shall provide written notice to the timber harvester specifying the actions which we required to be taken by the timber harvester to correct said condition(s). The timber harvester shall complete all such repairs within 15 days from the date of such notice. (b) If the necessary repairs to the county roads and/or public property are not completed within the required period of time, or if the repairs are not made in accordance with applicable standards which are acceptable to the county, the county may proceed to remedy said defects in accordance with the applicable specifications and requirements using the proceeds from any surety bond posted pursuant to this article to pay for such work. To the extent that any portion of a surety bond is not required or used, said excess amount shall be repaid to the permit holder. (c) Any timber harvester who does not take appropriate corrective action to remedy the designated problem shall pay all costs incurred by the county to repair any problems and return the public property to as good a condition as existed prior to the issuance of the permit. The county may use its own personnel to take said corrective action or may enter into such contracts with independent contractors as may be deemed reasonable and necessary to return the county roads and/or public property used by the timber harvesters to as good a condition as existed prior to the issuance of the permit. (d) In the event of violation of any provision or requirement of this article, the county shall issue a stop order directed to the timber harvester specifying the provision of this article alleged to have been violated and shall direct that necessary corrective action be taken within a reasonable time to be prescribed in the order. For the purpose of this section, a reasonable time shall not be greater than five days unless otherwise determined by the county, and may be less than five days if such lesser is deemed appropriate by the county. The order shall state that it shall become final within 15 days after the date of such order unless a request for a hearing is filed within that time with the county. Such order shall be delivered to the timber harvester either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested. When an emergency exists, no stop order shall be required to be issued by the county to the timber harvester. (e) In addition to any other penalties provided for under the provisions of this article, or under the provision of any state or federal law, any timber harvester in violation of this article shall reimburse the county for any costs and expenses incurred by the county in abating any nuisance created by the timber harvester. (f) Any action taken by the county to suspend or revoke a permit issued hereunder shall not preclude, and may be in addition to, any criminal prosecution by a proper authority as provided by the laws and ordinances of the county, the State of Georgia, or the United States. (g) Whenever any action is taken by the county to suspend or revoke any permit issued hereunder, the county shall provide written notice to the permit holder of the action taken stating the reasons thereof. Notice shall be delivered to the permit holder, either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested. The permit holder shall have 15 days following notification of such action to request a hearing before the county. The permit holder shall be entitled at such hearing to present evidence and to cross examine witnesses. Any decision of the county may be appealed to the superior court of the county by filing a written notice of appeal within 30 days of the county's decision. (h) Notwithstanding any other provisions contained elsewhere in this article, the following are declared to be criminal violations of this article: (1) It shall be unlawful to engage in any activities in violation of applicable requirements, rules, regulations, permits, permit conditions and orders established under this article. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (2) To furnish false or material incomplete or misleading information to the county, or a lawful designee of the county, on any application or investigation. (3) It shall be unlawful for any person to damage any public property or county road while engaged in the cutting or hauling of timber. (i) Jurisdiction over offenses in this article shall be in the magistrate court of the county. Any person violating the terms of this article or any permit condition may be punished by a fine of not less than $300.00 nor more than $1,000.00, or imprisoned in the county jail for a period not to exceed 60 days, or both. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § VII) Sec. 19-37. - Enforcement. The department head of the county road department, or his designated representative, shall be the enforcing officer of this article. (Ord. of 10-21-97, § VIII) ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS
Sec. 19-38. - Permit required. Any person or firm who engages in the selling of, attempting to sell, or providing of any service or product or advice by means of direct personal solicitation at any residence or business located in Catoosa County shall first obtain a permit from the county. (Ord. of 7-6-04, § 1) Sec. 19-39. - Authority. The permit authority shall be the Catoosa County Zoning Department. The cost of an annual permit is established at $150.00. The zoning department is authorized to adopt regulations to monitor permitted persons and firms and their activities for the protection of the public against fraud. (Ord. of 7-6-04, § 1) Sec. 19-40. - Exceptions. This article shall not apply to persons engaged in fund raising for local schools, local churches, or local community organizations, and national organizations recognized for promoting good morals and public health like the Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts, Muscular Dystrophy Association, American Cancer Society, and similar. This article shall not apply to licensed professionals engaged in the pursuit of their profession. "Professional" means a profession, which is regulated by the State of Georgia in Title 35 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. This article shall not apply to activities via the U.S. Mail or email. (Ord. of 7-6-04, § 1) Sec. 19-41. - Violation. A violation of this article is declared a misdemeanor offense. The sheriff, the zoning department, or such other officer authorized by the board of commissioners may write citations for violations. Punishment for violation shall be as within the general provisions for violations of county ordinances, including but not limited to maximum and minimum penalties. (Ord. of 7-6-04, § 1) Secs. 19-42—19-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - REGULATION OF PAIN MANAGEMENT CLINICS[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-001, §§ 2—7, adopted March 6, 2012, did not specifically amend the code. Hence inclusion as §§ 19-51—19-59 was at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 19-51. - Definitions. As used within this article, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth herein: Business entity or business entities shall mean means one or more persons engaging in activities for a profit, either individually or through the use of any of the following: company or corporation; general partnership; joint venture; limited liability company; limited liability partnership; limited partnership; sole proprietorship; a trust; or any other corporate or related entity similar in nature or function to any of those listed above. CARF International shall mean the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities, an Arizona nonprofit corporation, or its successor. Church shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. Drug addiction treatment center shall mean a clinic, facility, office, or business that satisfies all of the following requirements: (1) It is established for the purpose of treating addiction to illegal drugs or pain medications by administering opoids or other controlled substances; and, (2) All persons administering opoids or any controlled substance has a current certification issued to him or her by the administrator, substance abuse and mental health services administration (SAMHSA); and, (3) The clinic, facility, office, or business has a current certification issued to it by CARF International. Hospital shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. Hospital authority shall have the same meaning as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 31-7-72, as amended. Pain management clinic shall mean either: (1) Any entity, location, or business regardless of the name of the entity and regardless of the name displayed for the general public, which fulfills all of the following criteria: a. A privately owned clinic, medical practice, business, entity, or office; b. Which is owned by one or more persons or other business entity; c. The intention of which is for it to be operated for a profit; d. That is not affiliated with any of the following: 1. Any facility for the treatment of the terminally ill; or, 2. A hospital authority; or, 3. A non-profit health organization; or, 4. Any hospice; or 5. Any hospital; and, e. Which employs one or more physicians who are primarily engaged in the treatment of pain by prescribing pain medicine; or, (2) Any entity, location, or business regardless of the name of the entity and regardless of the name displayed for the general public, which fulfills all of the following criteria: a. Any clinic, medical practice, business, entity or office; b. Which dispenses schedule II, III, or IV drugs. Excluded from this definition is a an entity engaged in the practice of pharmacy which derives less than 25 percent of its gross revenue from the sales of schedule II, III, or IV drugs; hospitals; physician groups owned or operated by a health care system; surgery centers; in-patient care facilities; assisted living facilities; outpatient facilities owned or operated by a hospital system; any facility owned or operated by a hospital authority; any rehabilitation center where a portion of the patients reside at the center; any nursing home where a portion of the patients reside at the nursing home, and drug addiction treatment centers. Pain management clinic business license shall mean the business license issued under or pursuant to this article. Pain medicine shall mean: (1) Any medicine requiring a prescription and which contains narcotic analgesics or opoids, including, but not limited to, fentanyl, hydrocodone, morphine, or oxcycodone; and, (2) Any Schedule II, III, or IV drugs. Park shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. Person shall mean a naturally born person or a business entity. Physician shall mean a person licensed to practice medicine under or pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-34-21. Physician primarily engaged in treatment of pain shall mean a physician who provides a majority of his or her patients with a written prescription for one or more pain medications. Practice of pharmacy shall mean the interpretation, evaluation, or dispensing of prescription drug orders in the patient's best interest; participation in drug and device selection, drug administration, drug regimen reviews, and drug or drug related research; provision of patient counseling and the provision of those acts or services necessary to provide pharmacy care; performing capillary blood tests and interpreting the results as a means to screen for or monitor disease risk factors and facilitate patient education, and a pharmacist performing such functions shall report the results obtained from such blood tests to the patient's physician of choice; and the responsibility for compounding and labeling of drugs and devices, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 26-4-4, as amended. Residence shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. Schedule II, III, or IV drugs shall mean the drugs defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-13-26 through and including 16-13-29, as amended. School shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. Sensitive use structure shall mean a church, building owned or leased by a school (public or private), governmentally owned and operated building, library building, civic center building, park, hospital building, community club building, prison building, jail building, building owned or leased by a hospital authority, or any residence. Sexually oriented business shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. 12-001, § 2, 3-16-12) Sec. 19-52. - Business license required; application. (a) Business license. Any pain management clinic operating within the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County must obtain a valid pain management clinic business license from Catoosa County. (b) Filing requirements. An applicant for a pain management clinic business license shall file in person at the Catoosa County Planning and Zoning Office a completed application made on a form provided by the county's chief planning and zoning official or his or her designee. (c) Requirements of application. The applicant for a pain management business license must provide the following information: (1) The applicant's full legal name and any other names used by the applicant in the preceding five years. (2) If the license is to be held in the name of a business entity, the full legal name of that business entity and the names of persons who have any ownership interest (whether legal or equitable) in that business entity including, but not limited to, the names of all of the business entity's shareholders, partners (general and limited), members, managers, directors, and officers. (3) The current business address for both the individual applying for the license and for the business entity, if any, that he or she represents. (4) A statement as to whether any of the following persons has been convicted of a felony, has plead guilty to a felony, or has plead nolo contendre to a felony in any state within the five years preceding the date of the application for a pain management clinic business license: a. The applicant; b. Any person who has an ownership interest in the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license, whether such ownership interest is legal or equitable; c. Any of the partners (general or limited), shareholders, or members of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; d. Any of the directors of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; and, e. Any of the officers or managers of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license. (5) If any of the persons named in subsection 19-52(c)(4) has been convicted of a felony, plead guilty to a felony, or plead nolo contendre to a felony within the five years preceding the date of the application for a pain management clinic business license, the application must also set forth the following: a. The name of the person who was so convicted, plead guilty, or plead nolo contendre; b. Provide a complete description of the crime, including nature of the offense(s), the date of the plea or conviction, the name of the court where it occurred, the name under which the plea or conviction occurred, and the penalty assessed. (6) If any of the persons named in subsection 19-52(c)(4) has been convicted of a felony, plead guilty to a felony, or plead nolo contendre to a felony, all such felonies shall be listed on the application. (7) The names of all other business entities in which any of the following persons own any interest shall be listed on the application: a. The applicant; b. Any of the partners (general or limited), shareholders, or members of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; c. Any of the directors of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; and, d. Any of the officers or managers of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license. (8) The names of all physicians who will be writing or issuing any prescriptions for any pain medicine at the pain management clinic. (d) Items accompanying application. The applicant shall submit the following items with the application for a business license: (1) A driver's license or government-issued identification showing that the applicant is more than 18 years of age; (2) A copy of the articles of incorporation and bylaws, or articles of organization and operating agreement, or partnership agreement of the business entity that will be operating under the pain management business license; (3) Signed, notarized authorizations from the following persons authorizing the county to conduct a GCIC/NCIC criminal records background check: a. The applicant; b. All of the partners, shareholders, or members of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; c. All of the directors of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; d. All of the officers of the business entity that will operate under the pain management clinic business license; e. All of the physicians that will be writing prescriptions at the pain management clinic. (4) The name and DEA number of every physician who: a. Is to practice at the pain management clinic; b. Is employed in any capacity at the pain management clinic; c. Is an independent contractor or consultant retained by the pain management clinic; or d. Who has a financial or ownership interest in the pain management clinic. (5) A statement concerning whether the pain management clinic will dispense schedule II, III, or IV drugs. (6) A blue line copy of a surveyor's plat, eight and one-half inches by 11 inches in size, with a scale of one inch per 200 feet. The surveyor's plat shall show the proposed location and the location of all customer or patient entries in relation to distance, measured as provided in this article, to all real property and buildings on such real property which fall within the distance requirements as provided in this article, together with zoning district and present uses of all such real property and the proposed location. (7) A legal description of the property where the pain management clinic is either currently located or at which it will be located upon issuance of a pain management clinic business license. (e) Application to be signed and notarized. The application shall be signed under oath and all information contained in the application and all attachments is to be verified as true and accurate by: (1) If the applicant is an individual, the individual; (2) If a partnership, a general partner; (3) If a corporation, the president of the corporation; (4) If a limited liability company, either the manager or the managing member; (5) If any other type of business entity, the chief executive officer or chief administrative officer of the business entity. (f) Pain management business license application fee. The pain management clinic business license fee shall be as set by the Catoosa County Board of Commissioners and published in the application for a pain management clinic business license. Should the application fail to set forth a fee, the fee shall be $400.00 as the initial application fee. The fee to renew a pain management clinic business license shall be $400.00, unless a different rate is published on the application issued by the Catoosa County Board of Commissioners. (g) Applicant to assure application complete. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to assure that the application for a pain management clinic business license is complete. No employee of Catoosa County shall have any responsibility to notify the applicant of any deficiency in the application. The fact that the county accepts the application from the applicant is not an indication that the application is either correct or complete. (Ord. No. 12-001, § 3, 3-6-12) Sec. 19-53. - Issuance of business license. (a) Issuance or denial of application. Within 45 days from and after the filing of a completed application for a pain management clinic business license, the Chief Planning and Zoning Official of Catoosa County shall either issue a license to the applicant or deny a license to the applicant. Any denial of an application for a pain management clinic business license may be appealed to the board of commissioners utilizing the appeal provisions contained in section 6-229 of the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances. Notwithstanding any provisions in the Catoosa County Code of Ordinances to the contrary, no pain management clinic business license shall be issued during the pendency of any such appeal. (b) Grant of license. The pain management clinic business license may be granted if: (1) The application is complete and conforms to all of the provisions of this article. (2) The required fee has been paid. (3) The application does not contain a material misrepresentation of fact. (4) The applicant has fully cooperated in the review of that application. (5) None of the following persons have plead guilty to a felony, plead nolo contendre to a felony, or been convicted of a felony: a. If the applicant is an individual, the applicant; b. If the applicant is a business entity, any of the persons holding a financial or ownership interest in that business entity whether such interest is legal or equitable; c. If the applicant is a corporation, any of the officers; d. If the applicant is a limited liability company, any of the managers. (6) The applicant, if a business entity, is in good standing with the Georgia Secretary of State. (7) All criminal background checks have been completed by the Catoosa County Sheriff's Department. (c) Expiration. Each and every business license issued to a pain management clinic shall expire one year from and after the date it is issued. (d) Completion date of application. The application for a pain management clinic business license is completed on the date that the city receives the last piece of information or document for such application as required by this article. (Ord. No. 12-001, § 4, 3-6-12) Sec. 19-54. - Renewal of pain management business license. Any person seeking to renew a pain management clinic business license must provide all of the information required by this article for the initial application for said license. Each renewal shall expire one year from and after the date on which it issued. (Ord. No. 12-001, § 5, 3-6-12) Sec. 19-55. - Prohibited acts. (a) It shall be unlawful to establish, operate, or cause to be operated a pain management clinic in the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County unless said pain management clinic is located at least 500 feet from another pain management clinic. For purposes of measuring the distance imposed by this sub-paragraph, the measurement shall be made in a straight line in all directions without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the primary point of pedestrian entry of the structure in which the applicant is located to the primary point of pedestrian entry of structure of the nearest other pain management clinic. (b) It shall be unlawful to establish, operate or cause to be operated a pain management clinic in the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County unless said pain management clinic is located at least 500 feet from any sensitive use structure. For purposes of measuring the distance imposed by this sub-paragraph, the measurement shall be made in a straight line in all directions, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the primary point of pedestrian entry of the structure in which the applicant is located to the primary point of pedestrian entry of sensitive use structure. If the sensitive use structure is a park, the measurement shall be to the public entry point to the park closest the proposed pain management clinic. (c) It shall be unlawful to establish, operate, or cause to be operated a pain management clinic in the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County unless said pain management clinic is located at least 500 feet from a business licensed to sell alcohol on the premises, whether by the package or for consumption. For purposes of measuring the distance imposed by this sub-paragraph, the measurement shall be in a straight line in all directions, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the primary point of pedestrian entry to the structure in which the applicant is located to the primary point of pedestrian entry of premises holding the license to sell alcohol. (d) It shall be unlawful to establish, operate, or cause to be operated a pain management clinic in the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County unless said pain management clinic is located at least 500 feet from any sexually oriented business. For purposes of measuring the distance imposed by this sub-paragraph, the measurement shall be in a straight line in all directions, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the primary point of pedestrian entry to the structure in which the applicant is located to the primary point of pedestrian entry of the sexually oriented business. (e) It shall be unlawful for any pain management clinic to employ, in any capacity, a physician who is on probation for issues relating to dispensing controlled substances. (f) It shall be unlawful for any pain management clinic to employ, in any capacity, a physician who has had his or her license to practice medicine suspended or revoked by any medical board. (g) It shall be unlawful for a physician who is on probation or whose license to practice medicine has been suspended or revoked for issues relating to dispensing controlled substances to own any type of financial interest, legal or equitable, in a pain management clinic. (h) It shall be unlawful to operate a pain management clinic on any property which is not zoned as one of the commercial zoning designations as more particularly enumerated under the Catoosa County Zoning Ordinance. (i) It shall be unlawful to operate a pain management clinic without first obtaining a special use permit, the requirements of which are more fully enumerated in the Catoosa County Zoning Ordinance. (j) It shall be unlawful to operate a pain management clinic without a pain management clinic business license issued under the requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 12-001, § 6, 3-6-12) Sec. 19-56. - Penalties for prohibited acts. Enforcement for violations of this article shall be carried out in accordance with this section: (a) Remedies cumulative. The remedies provided in this article are cumulative and in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity. (b) Effect on pain management business license. (1) Upon a violation of subparagraphs (a)—(d) or subparagraphs (h) or (i) of section 19-55 of this article, the pain management clinic business license shall be revoked. (2) Upon a violation of subparagraphs (e)—(g) or subparagraph (j) of section 19-55 of this section, the pain management clinic business license shall be suspended as follows: a. On the first such violation, the pain management clinic business license shall be suspended for a time period not to exceed 90 days; b. On the second such violation, the pain management clinic business license shall be suspended for a time period not to exceed 180 days; c. On the third such violation, the pain management clinic business license shall be suspended for a time period not to exceed 360 days; and, d. On the fourth such violation, the pain management clinic business license shall be revoked and neither the applicant nor the business entity under which it was operating may apply for a pain management clinic business license in the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County for a period of five years. (Ord. No. 12-001, § 7, 3-6-12)

div.head: Chapter 20 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 20-1—20-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 20-26. - Curfew. (a) Institution of curfew. (1) Upon the declaration of the state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the county governing authority, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the county governing authority, or its designee or the emergency interim successor may adopt a resolution instituting a curfew when it is determined necessary to protect and safeguard the people and property of the county. (2) All of the territory of the unincorporated county shall be subject to the terms of the curfew, unless otherwise specified in the resolution. (3) The resolution instituting the curfew shall include the dates and hours that the curfew shall be in effect. (b) Definitions. (1) Curfew. A "curfew" is a regulation requiring the withdrawal from any person not otherwise exempt from this section from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. (2) Exempt individuals. Unless otherwise specified in the resolution implementing the curfew, "exempt individuals" include those individuals engaged in the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, emergency medical services and hospital services, utility emergency repairs. The resolution may, in the discretion of the governing authority, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, new media employees, building and repair contractors, properly registered according to the county ordinance to require registration and licensing of building and repair services during a state of emergency, performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. (3) State of emergency.
