In outline, the procedure for accepting restricted waste will include the following steps: (1) All generators, established or new, must inform the county solid waste management department of the need to dispose of waste. (2) The generator must specify in writing the source and materials contained in the waste. (3) Analytical characterization of the county solid waste management department. Such analyses will be performed by an independent laboratory, at the expense of the generator. (4) Additional costs incurred by the county solid waste management department in the disposal operation of restricted waste will be borne by the generator. These costs will be determined by the county solid waste management department. (5) The county solid waste management department will make all determinations and decisions as to the acceptability of the waste. (6) The acceptance and handling of all restricted waste will be documented in writing, and such documentation will be maintained for 30 years after closure of the county solid waste management facility. Documentation will include: a. A waste profile form; b. An analytical sampling plan and analytical results, as appropriate, including laboratory identification; c. A signed county solid waste management department waste acceptance form having acceptance or rejection noted, with the reason indicated; and d. A disposal contract. (b) A list of all generators or restricted wastes that have had waste accepted or have otherwise demonstrated waste acceptability to the county solid waste management department will be maintained by the county solid waste management department. Any generator proposing to dispose of restricted waste must be listed before the county solid waste management department personnel will accept such waste. (c) Policies and procedures for specific restricted waste such as asbestos, drums, liquids, dewatered latex waste, electrical distribution equipment and capacitors, petroleum-contaminated soils are available. Other materials and substances may be added to the specific restricted waste category, and it is the responsibility of the generator to remain apprised of such additions. All generators having contracts with the county solid waste management department will be notified of such actions. (d) In all cases priority will be given to domestic waste, industrial waste and commercial waste generated in the county. (1) Only domestic and commercial solid waste generated within the county is permitted to be disposed of at the county solid waste management facilities, and the tipping fee for this type of waste will be charged for such use. (2) It is the intention of the county solid waste management department to accept only industrial wastes that have been approved by the environmental protection division and deemed appropriated by the county solid waste management department. All such wastes will be evaluated as to origin, chemical composition and quantity. (3) No hazardous waste will be accepted. No person shall deposit or attempt to deposit hazardous waste on the county solid waste landfill property or other county property. No material other than commercial, municipal or industrial waste that has been approved by the environmental protection division and the county solid waste management department may be deposited at the landfill. (4) Biomedical waste from sources generating less than 100 pounds per month may be deposited in the county landfill. All persons delivering biomedical waste shall declare the biomedical waste at the time it is delivered for disposal. Biomedical waste generating over 100 pounds per month may not be disposed of in the county landfill unless it is treated and deemed acceptable by the county solid waste management department. (5) Asbestos must be wetted and bagged in 12-mil (minimum) thickness polyethylene bags or must be wetted, packed in six-mil polyethylene bags in fiber drums. Only asbestos waste generated in the county may be accepted. All state environmental protection division rules and regulations must be followed with respect to wetting and bagging the materials. Materials must be wet when received at the county solid waste management facilities. A surcharge per ton as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk will be added for the special handling required by asbestos waste. The county solid waste management department must be given an advance notice of the intent to dispose of asbestos waste at its facilities, and asbestos waste will be accepted for disposal by appointment only. (6) Bulky waste will be accepted if generated in the county, with the following exceptions. a. Appliances with chlorofluorocarbon-containing refrigerant such as air conditioners, refrigerators, freezers, etc. b. Carpet wastes from a manufacturer, including carpet scraps, ends and "strings" from the manufacturing process will be accepted if bailed or shredded at the fee rate noted in section 66-40. If carpet wastes are not bailed or shredded, a surcharge per ton as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk will be added for extra volume and handling. c. Cardboard carpet rolls unless baled or cut into four-foot lengths. (7) Construction and demolition waste that originates in the county will be accepted if it does not contain any industrial waste components. (8) Tires will be accepted only from the county. (9) Prior to depositing their loads at the county solid waste management facilities, all haulers must declare loads that consist, in whole or in part, of outside of county solid waste; if a load that includes outside county solid waste is deposited at the county solid waste management facilities, 200 percent of the tipping fee for county solid waste shall be applied and charged to the entire load. (Ord. of 5-18-93(2), § 9) Sec. 66-40. - Fee schedule. Fees for the following services are established. These fees are as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. The board of commissioners reserves the right to amend any or all fees on 30 days' public notice: (1) Landfill. (2) Tires. a. Processed tires. b. Unprocessed tires. (3) All persons shall pay a fee for commercial, industrial and institutional refuse deposited in the county solid waste management facilities. Commercial refuse shall include building materials, business trash and permitted industrial waste and any other material hauled to the county solid waste management facilities for a fee resulting out of commercial activity. As a condition precedent to commercial use of the county solid waste management facilities, a deposit shall be made with the county or the user shall be required to pay in advance the amount of the fee at the time of the proposed use. The deposit shall not bear interest and shall be for the purpose of applying such a deposit to unpaid and past-due tipping fees. Charges for commercial uses of the county solid waste management facilities shall be due within ten days of receipt of a statement from the county solid waste management department. (4) Residents of the county other than commercial, industrial and institutional collectors, and private companies collecting wastes from residents, may use public sites without charges, in accordance with the regulations for the particular site and under instruction of the attendant. However, effective August 1, 1993, residential users will be charged for the following services fees as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk: a. Landfill. 1. By the bag. 2. By the pickup truck load. b. Tires, with a maximum of four tires per visit. (5) Residents may dispose of garbage by the bag with no charge if recyclable materials that are accepted by the county solid waste management department are also deposited separately from waste. The recyclable material must be of a volume equivalent to half the volume of waste brought for disposal. (6) An exception will be made for debris created by a natural disaster. This waste will be accepted from county residents only at no charge for up to a 30-day period following the natural disaster. The waste accepted for disposal shall be waste created as a direct result of the natural disaster and must be nonhazardous solid waste that would normally be accepted by the landfill. (Ord. of 5-18-93(2), § 10) Sec. 66-41. - Facility rules for haulers. (a) Liability of the county solid waste management department. All persons shall proceed onto the county solid waste management facilities at their own risk. The county solid waste management department shall not be liable for errors or omissions of its contractors, persons using the solid waste management facility, or other third persons in or about the solid waste management facility. (b) Reservations of rights by the county solid waste management department: (1) Disposal privileges of haulers are limited to municipal, commercial, industrial and institutional waste. The county solid waste management department reserves the right to inspect any load coming into the county solid waste management facility. The disposal of any material other than specifically approved by the county solid waste management department may result in a permanent revocation of disposal privileges. Liquid waste and hazardous waste are specifically prohibited. Other waste may, in the discretion of the county solid waste management department, be allowed only if the hauler has submitted an application to the environmental protection division and the county solid waste management department and has received approval by both agencies for the disposal. (2) If the county solid waste management department determines that any material or waste has been deposited that is in violation of any law or the county solid waste management department's rules and regulations, the county solid waste management department may require the hauler and/or the generator with the expense of removing the unauthorized waste. The hauler and/or the generator will remain responsible for disposal of such waste in an approved facility. (3) The county solid waste management department has the right to require the hauler and/or the generator to file a manifest for each load of any type of solid waste deposited at the landfill showing the source of all solid waste and a statement signed by the hauler and/or the generator of the solid waste certifying that the solid waste is municipal or commercial waste and describing the contents and/or the origin thereof. (c) Contracts. In all specifics, haulers and their agents and/or employees must abide by the terms of any and all contracts entered into between the county solid waste management department and hauler. (d) General rules. The following are general rules of the county solid waste management facilities: (1) Smoking and alcohol consumption is prohibited at the county solid waste management facilities except where expressly permitted. (2) No person under the age of 18 shall be permitted to enter the facility in any waste collection or disposal vehicle. (3) Loitering on and about the county solid waste management facilities is prohibited. (4) It is the duty and responsibility of the hauler and other persons using the county solid waste management facilities to familiarize themselves with and to obey the rules of the facilities, as such rules may be changed or new rules adopted and posted on the premises. (5) All persons shall conduct themselves and operate their vehicles safely at all times and in all operations at the county solid waste management facilities. (6) No unauthorized person shall have salvage rights to any materials deposited at the county solid waste management facilities. (7) In order to prevent litter on and about the county solid waste management facilities, all loads of solid waste and roll-off boxes shall be covered with tarpaulins. The transporting of waste in hoppers of rear loading vehicles or on or about any vehicle except for the space designed to hold solid waste is prohibited. (Ord. of 5-18-93(2), § 11) Sec. 66-42. - Operational rules and regulations. (a) A violation of improper and permitted dumping shall result in the following: (1) A warning of permit suspension for the first violation; (2) One week's suspension of permit and dumping privileges for the second violation; (3) Three weeks' suspension of permit and dumping privileges for the third and all subsequent violations; (4) Indefinite suspension of dumping privileges for the fourth and all subsequent violations at the option of the county solid waste management department. (b) Violations of any rule, regulation and/or requirement contained in this article the penalty for which has not been heretofore specifically set forth shall result in the following: (1) A warning of permit suspension for the first violation; (2) Two day's suspension of permit and dumping privileges for the second violation; (3) One week's suspension of permit and dumping privileges for the third and all subsequent violations. (Ord. of 5-18-93(2), § 12) Sec. 66-43. - Penalties for violations. In addition to the sanctions provided in section 66-42, the following penalties apply: (1) Criminal penalties. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-19. Citations for violations of this article shall be issued by the head of the county solid waste management department. Trials for violations of this article shall be held in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. (2) Civil enforcement. The county attorney or any other attorney designated by the board of commissioners may file a civil action in the superior court of the county to enjoin any person from violating this article or to require such person to take remedial action necessary to correct a violation of this article, including the removal and proper disposal of any waste or hazardous waste disposed of in violation of this article. In addition the county may recover damages for the violation of this article and any expense incurred by the county to correct a violation of this article. The county may also recover its attorney's fees and expenses of litigation if the violation was intentional or the violator acted in bad faith, was stubbornly litigious, or caused the county unnecessary trouble or expense. (Ord. of 5-18-93(2), § 13) Sec. 66-44. - Credit policies. (a) At the discretion of the county solid waste management department manager, a bond in the amount of one month's worth of business or a letter of credit for that amount may be required. The bond or letter of credit for that amount may be required. The bond or letter of credit shall be adjustable as quantities of the waste disposed to landfill by the hauler change. (b) Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase of these regulations be declared unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, the remainder of these regulations shall not be affected thereby. (Ord. of 5-18-93(2), § 14) Secs. 66-45—66-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LITTER CONTROL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-007, adopted May 25, 2006, amended Art. III, which consisted of §§ 66-76—66-81, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former §§ 66-76—66-81 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from an ordinance adopted Jan. 22, 1991.
Sec. 66-76. - Findings; authority. The Catoosa County Board of Commissioners finds that litter found throughout Catoosa County often finds its way into the county's streams, rivers and lakes and detracts from the quality of life for the citizens of Catoosa County. Pollutants carried into the county's streams, rivers, and lakes by litter diminish the quality of the county's water and its aquatic resources. The Catoosa County Board of Commissioners deems it necessary to adopt this litter control ordinance in order to provide a prohibition against littering and to provide an enforcement mechanism with penalties for dealing with those found littering. This article is modeled on the "Georgia Litter Control Law" (O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et. seq.) and the adoption of this article is authorized by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48. (Ord. No. 06-007, § 1, 5-25-06) Sec. 66-77. - General provisions. (1) Purpose and intent. The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare of the citizens of Catoosa County, through the regulation and prevention of litter. The objectives of this article are to: (a) Provide for uniform prohibition throughout the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County of any and all littering on public or private property; and (b) Prevent the desecration of the beauty and quality of life of the citizens of Catoosa County and to prevent harm to the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare of said citizens, including the degradation of water and aquatic resources caused by litter. (2) Applicability. This article shall apply to all public and private property located within the unincorporated areas of Catoosa County, Georgia. (3) Compatibility with other regulations. This article is not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other ordinance, rule or regulation, statute, or other provision of law. The requirements of this article should be considered minimum requirements, and where any provision of this article impose restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall be considered to take precedence. (4) Severability. If the provisions of any article, section, subsection, paragraph, subdivision or clause of this article shall be judged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such order of judgment shall not affect or invalidate the remainder of any article, section, subsection, paragraph, subdivision or clause of this article. (Ord. No. 06-007, § 2, 5-25-06) Sec. 66-78. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: (a) Litter means any organic or inorganic waste material, rubbish, refuse, garbage, trash, hulls, peelings, debris, grass, weeds, ashes, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, metal, plastic, and glass containers, broken glass, dead animals or intentionally or unintentionally discarded materials of every kind and description which are not "waste" as such term is defined in O.C.G.A., § 16-7-51(6). (b) Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the banks, shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; timberlands or forests; and residential, commercial, industrial, or farm properties. (Ord. No. 06-007, § 3, 5-25-06) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 66-79. - Prohibition against littering public or private property or waters. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, deposit, throw or leave or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property in Catoosa County or any waters within Catoosa County unless: (a) The property is designated by the state or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property for the disposal of such litter; (b) The litter is placed into a receptacle or container installed on such property; or (c) The person is either the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or is performing the act under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. (Ord. No. 06-007, § 4, 5-25-06) Sec. 66-80. - Vehicle loads causing litter. No person shall operate any motor vehicle with a load on or in such vehicle unless the load on or in such vehicle is adequately secured to prevent the dropping or shifting of litter or materials from such load onto the roadways of Catoosa County. (Ord. No. 06-007, § 5, 5-25-06) Sec. 66-81. - Violations, enforcement and penalties. (1) Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article. Any person who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article may be subject to the enforcement actions outlined in this section or may be restrained by injunction or otherwise sentenced in a manner provided by law. (2) Evidence. (a) Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, or other conveyance in violation of this article, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this article. (b) Except as provided in subsection (a), whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this article is discovered to contain any article or articles, including, but not limited to, letters, bills, publications or other writing, which display the name of the person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this article. (3) Penalties. Any person who violates this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: (a) By a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $1,000.00 per violation; and (b) In addition to the fine set out in subsection (a) above, the violator shall reimburse Catoosa County for the reasonable cost of removing the litter when the litter is or is ordered removed by Catoosa County; and (c) In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to either: 1. Pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of way for a distance not to exceed one mile any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; or 2. Pick up and remove any and all litter from any public property, private right-of-way, or with prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter. Pick up and removal shall include any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence; and (d) The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating this article. (4) Enforcement. All law enforcement agencies, officers and officials of this state or any political subdivision thereof, or any enforcement agency, officer or any official of any commission of this state or any political subdivision thereof, are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this article. (Ord. No. 06-007, § 6, 5-25-06) Secs. 66-82—66-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS WASTE
Sec. 66-116. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dispose means the discharge, deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking, placing of any solid waste or hazardous waste into or on any land or water so that such solid waste or hazardous waste or any constituent thereof may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including groundwaters, burning, incinerating, or by any other means of depositing hazardous or toxic waste onto or into the air, land or water, including groundwater. Existing facility means as a hazardous waste facility holding a valid permit issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-60 et seq., on July 24, 1990, the provisions of this article shall fully apply to all permitted facilities whose permit is the subject to an appeal or judicial review as of July 24, 1990, and such facilities whose permits are the subject of an appeal or judicial review on July 24, 1990, shall not be construed to be holding a valid permit on July 24, 1990. Existing facility shall also include the successor or transferee of an owner or operator of a hazardous waste facility that holds such valid permit on July 24, 1990, and whose hazardous waste facility is located in the county. Hazardous waste means any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the Federal Act which is now in force and effect on February 1, 1988, codified as 40 CFR section 261.3 and any designated hazardous waste. Hazardous waste facility means any property or facility that is intended or used for storage, treatment, or disposal of hazardous waste, with the exception of the following businesses (which shall not be defined as hazardous waste facilities because of their history in this county for safety, and because of the familiarity of emergency response entities to respond to incidences at the following facilities): Service stations where liquids are used as motor fuels and are stored and dispensed from fixed equipment into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles; oil change businesses which service the changing of oil on automobiles, motorcycles, and other motor vehicles; automotive mechanic shops; automotive body shops; automotive garages; provided that such excepted facilities use the tract of land upon which such businesses are located exclusively for the excepted uses or uses incidental thereto (such as convenience stores, food markets, facilities for the sale and service of tires, facilities for the sale and service of batteries and accessories and the sale of gifts and other crafts). Solid waste means solid waste as defined by regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the Federal Act which is now in force and effect on February 1, 1988, codified as 40 CFR Sections 621.1, 621.2(a) through (d), and 261-4(a). Storage means the containment or holding of hazardous waste, either on a temporary basis or for a period of years, in such a manner as not to constitute disposal of such hazardous waste. Transport means the transportation or carrying of hazardous waste in a storage tank, drum, tanker, or other container on or in a motor vehicle (except within a tank being used to feed or supply the motor vehicle with a means of energy for locomotion at the time of transport) on roads on the county system of roads. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 66-117. - Operation of vehicles with headlights. All motor vehicle trucks, including tanker trucks, transporting hazardous waste on roads on the county road system shall operate with their headlights on at all times. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 2(a)) Cross reference— Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 74. Sec. 66-118. - Equipment on trucks. All motor vehicle trucks and truck tankers transporting hazardous waste on roads on the county road system shall be equipped with two-way radios or citizens band radios capable of receiving from and transmitting to the sheriff's office or the county ambulance service at all times. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 2(b)) Sec. 66-119. - Parking of vehicles. No driver of a motor vehicle or truck tanker transporting hazardous waste on roads on the county road system shall leave such vehicle at any place in the unincorporated areas of the county (with the exception of the hazardous waste facility) without intermittently checking on the vehicle while parked at least on 15-minute intervals to ascertain the safety of the parking of the vehicle, whether the vehicle is leaking hazardous waste, and for other safety factors. A vehicle may be left unattended when safely parked while the driver is eating for up to 30 minutes. In the event of a break-down or accident, the vehicle transporting hazardous waste may be left unattended only if the driver is rendered incapable of remaining at the vehicle due to the injuries received in the accident, or if the driver radios the sheriff's office and a deputy remains with such vehicle. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 2(c)) Sec. 66-120. - Backing vehicles. No driver of a motor vehicle truck or truck tanker transporting hazardous waste on the below-referenced routes in the county shall back such vehicle (drive, or otherwise cause such vehicle to be moved in a backward direction) upon any shoulder of a roadway or onto (from the shoulder, right-of-way or other property to the pavement) any roadway of a road on the county road system having a traffic count of more than 1,440 cars per day (as shown on the most recent state department of transportation traffic count. If no traffic count exists, the proposed facility shall contact the office of the board of commissioners in writing to request such traffic count; the board of commissioners shall provide a traffic count within 90 days, which shall be determinative of the traffic count contemplated in this article; if the board of commissioners provides no traffic count within such 90-day period, it shall be presumed that the traffic count is less than 1,440 cars per day except during an emergency traffic condition that would either render such vehicle in an unsafe position on the roadway or upon the direction of a law enforcement officer (by either the request of the driver or by the command of such officer). (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 2(d)) Sec. 66-121. - Conditions on hazardous waste facility. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to own, establish, operate or maintain a hazardous waste facility in the unincorporated areas of the county unless such facility is in compliance with all of the conditions set forth in this article on hazardous waste facilities. (b) No person shall dispose of any hazardous waste in the unincorporated areas of the county unless any ponds or pools storing or disposing of hazardous waste shall have a liner composed of the same materials required for liners in newly constructed landfills in regulations promulgated by the environmental protection agency. (c) All persons that dispose of any hazardous waste in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be subject to an inspection without warrant or notice that may be issued by the emergency response coordinator in the event of an emergency relating to the conditions at such facility. An emergency shall be defined as a complaint or information received by such coordinator of a violation of this article that may affect safety of persons or property. (d) No person shall operate a hazardous waste facility in the unincorporated areas of the county unless they shall have first obtained and unless they maintain a 500-yard setback buffer distance from the nearest building line of the nearest dwelling. No person shall operate a hazardous waste facility in the unincorporated areas of the county unless they shall have first obtained and unless they maintain a 350-yard setback buffer distance from the nearest building line of nondwelling building structures used for human occupancy (such as businesses, industrial buildings, commercial offices, etc.). No person shall operate a hazardous waste facility in the unincorporated areas of the county unless they shall have first obtained and unless they maintain a 100-yard setback buffer distance from private property lines. The setbacks for dwelling and nondwelling structures used for human occupancy are imposed for health and safety reasons. The 100-yard setback from private property lines are for the purpose of aesthetic reasons. The minimum setback distance shall be from the nearest point of any building, container, tank, pond or pool that is used for the storage or disposal of hazardous waste to the nearest private property line, dwelling building line, or nondwelling structure building line used for human occupancy in all directions (i.e., a radius in all directions). (e) No person shall expand any existing hazardous waste facility unless such facility is in full compliance with all of the terms of this article. The term expansion shall include but not be limited to the acquisition of additional land by such person for the storage or disposal of hazardous waste, as well as the use of any areas of property for the storage or disposal of hazardous waste not identified for storage or disposal on the site plan on file and approved by the office of the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources as of July 24, 1990 (the date of the original adoption of the expansion provision of this article). (f) Existing facilities must commence to take steps to comply with all of the terms of this article within 30 days from its adoption by the board of commissioners; such existing facilities must be in full compliance with the terms of this article within 90 days from its execution by the board of commissioners; however, no existing facility holding a valid permit on July 24, 1990, shall be compelled to comply with the terms of this article governing setback distances unless such existing facility engages in an expansion as defined in this article; if such existing facility engages in an expansion, it shall maintain the 100-yard setback buffer from perimeter property lines specified in this article, but shall not be required to maintain the remaining setback distance buffers. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 3) Sec. 66-122. - Compliance required. The disposal of any solid waste or hazardous waste or any hazardous constituent thereof on any land or water shall be unlawful in any unincorporated areas of the county if not done in strict compliance with this article. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 4) Sec. 66-123. - Enforcement. This article may be enforced by any lawful officer of the county, including but not limited to any officer of the sheriff's department, agent of the office of the board of commissioners, agent of the county health department, any other designee of the board of commissioners, or the emergency response coordinator for the county. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 5) Sec. 66-124. - Violation; penalty. Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be liable for a penalty specified in section 1-19. Furthermore, each transportation violation of this article constitutes a separate offense regardless of whether it occurs in one day, several transportations within a day, or at intervals shorter than a day within a week; that is, each transportation constitutes a separate offense, and if more than one transport of hazardous waste occurs within a day, each such transport may be prosecuted separately and shall constitute a separate offense. Whenever any provision of this article has been or is being violated, the appropriate county authority or any adjacent or neighboring property owner who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute an injunction or other appropriate actions or proceedings and prosecute the same to a final judgment to correct or abate such violation. (Ord. of 7-24-90, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 70 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Finance generally, § 2-191 et seq.; taxation of malt beverages sold in county, § 6-80; taxation of wine sold in county, § 6-105. Related law reference— Taxation, § 141 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 70-1. - Sales tax imposed. The local option sales tax is imposed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-83. (Res. of 12-17-79) Sec. 70-2. - Certain tax executions ineligible for transfer. (a) The tax executions on the following properties shall be excluded from transfer: (1) All tax executions less than 121 days past due. (2) All tax executions on property carrying an exemption granted to an individual who is over age 62. (3) All tax executions on property carrying an exemption granted to an individual as a veteran of the United States Armed Forces. (4) All tax executions on property owned, in whole or in part, by a disabled person. (5) All tax executions on property owned, in whole or in part, by a taxpayer who has entered into a written payment agreement with the county for the orderly payment of such taxes. (b) No tax execution on property shall be sold to third parties for less than full value. (Res. of 7-2-96, § 5) Sec. 70-3. - Waiver, assessment of penalties. The board of commissioners delegates the authority to the tax commissioner of the county to make the final determination on a case-by-case basis following sound business guidelines, and the tax commissioner is vested with the authority to make the final decision as to whether or not to waive or assess penalties on ad valorem taxes. (Res. of 7-18-95) Secs. 70-4—70-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF TAX ASSESSORS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-126 et seq.
Sec. 70-36. - Creation of board; duties; personnel. (a) Pursuant to the authority contained in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290, there is established in the county a board of tax assessors, which shall be known as the Catoosa County Board of Tax Assessors. (b) The board of tax assessors shall have the duties and responsibilities provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-299 and such other duties as may be imposed by general or special law. (c) The employees of the board of tax assessors shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the board of commissioners. (Res. of 12-30-96, § I) Sec. 70-37. - Qualifications; certain relationships prohibited. (a) Under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290(d), no individual shall be appointed or reappointed to a county board of tax assessors when the individual is related to a member of the board of commissioners in one of the following degrees: (1) Mother or mother-in-law; (2) Father or father-in-law; (3) Sister or sister-in-law; (4) Brother or brother-in-law; (5) Grandmother or grandmother by marriage; (6) Grandfather or grandfather by marriage; (7) Son or son-in-law; or (8) Daughter or daughter-in-law. (b) No individual shall serve as a member of the board of tax assessors: (1) Who is less than 21 years of age. (2) Who fails to make his residence within the county within six months after taking the oath of office as a member of the board. (3) Who does not hold a high school diploma or its equivalent (an individual who has held an equivalent responsible position of employment for a period of five years shall not be required to meet the high school education requirement provided in this subsection). (4) Who does not have at least one year's experience in appraisal-related work (the successful completion of 40 hours of approved appraisal courses provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-291(c) taken either prior to appointment or within one year after appointment, may be substituted for this experience requirement). (5) Who has not successfully completed an assessor examination to be administered by the commissioner or who has not successfully completed at least 40 hours of approved appraisal courses as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-291(c). (c) In addition, no member of the board of tax assessors shall be eligible to hold any state, county or municipal office during the time he holds office as a member of the board of tax assessors. (Res. of 12-30-96, § II) Sec. 70-38. - Number on board; posts; term of office; initial terms. (a) The board of tax assessors shall consist of five members, who shall be appointed for staggered terms to a post on the board of tax assessors. (b) The term of office, after the initial terms, of the members of the board of tax assessors shall be four years. (c) Each member of the board of tax assessors shall serve until their successors are duly appointed and take their oath of office. (d) A member of the board of tax assessors may be reappointed to succeed himself as a member. (e) The chief appraiser or a member of the county appraisal staff may serve as a member of the board of tax assessors. Any vacancy created on the board of tax assessors under this subsection shall be filled in the manner provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-295(a). If the member ceases to be employed as chief appraiser or a member of the county appraisal staff, the member shall cease to be a member of the board of tax assessors. (f) The appointment by the board of commissioners shall constitute the order of appointment and shall be regularly entered on the record of the superior court of the county in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290. The clerk of the superior court shall administer the oath of office as required by law. (Res. of 12-30-96, § III) Sec. 70-39. - Removal from office. Under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-295(b), a member of the board of tax assessors may be removed by the board of commissioners only for cause shown for the failure to perform the duties or meet the qualifications imposed upon the board member by law. No member of the county board of tax assessors who is also employed by the county as a staff appraiser may be removed by the board of commissioners during his term of appointment until the member has been afforded an opportunity for hearing before the judge of the superior court of the county for recommendations by the judge of the superior court to the board of commissioners regarding such removal. (Res. of 12-30-96, § V) Secs. 70-40—70-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INSURERS
Sec. 70-71. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Insurer means a company authorized to transact business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 70-72. - Life insurers license fees. There is levied an annual license fee upon each life insurer doing business within the county as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 70-73, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the county, there is levied a license fee as provided in such schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. Sec. 70-73. - License fee for life insurers insuring certain risks at additional business location. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee under this article, operated and maintained by a business organization engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales, an insurer who offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of a life insurer for life insurance shall pay an additional annual license fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. Sec. 70-74. - Life insurance agency license fees; independent life insurance agencies, brokers not otherwise licensed. There is levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which a life insurance business is conducted and is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 70-72 as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. Sec. 70-75. - Gross premiums tax—Life insurers. There is levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the county in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 70-72. Sec. 70-76. - All other insurers. There is levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the county in an amount equal to two and one-half percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Res. of 9-26-83) Sec. 70-77. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in this article shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year. Sec. 70-78. - License fees, all insurers doing business in the county. There is levied an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the county as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. For each separate business location in excess of one operating on behalf of such insurers within the county, there is levied a license fee as provided in such schedule of fees and charges. Secs. 70-79—70-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
Sec. 70-111. - Business license tax. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is levied an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, and state building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of such institutions. Gross receipts shall mean gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. Sec. 70-112. - Filing of return. Each depository financial institution within the county shall file a return of its gross receipts with the county on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Such returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in such return. Sec. 70-113. - Due date. The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1 of each year. Secs. 70-114—70-125. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - EXEMPTIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 70-126—70-150. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - FREEPORT EXEMPTION
Sec. 70-151. - Applicability. The board of commissioners hereby exempts from taxation, as hereinafter provided, the following classes of tangible personal property: (1) An exemption for inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. Provided, however, that the exemption provided for with respect to this class of tangible personal property shall apply only to tangible personal property which is substantially modified, altered, or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing, or production operations in the state. (2) An exemption for inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods. Provided, however, that such exemption shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is manufactured or produced. (3) An exemption for inventory of finished goods which, on January 1 of a given tax year, are stored in a warehouse, dock, or wharf, whether public or private, and which are destined for shipment outside the state and the inventory of finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside this state and which are stored for transshipment to a final destination outside this state. Provided, however, that such exemption shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in this state. (Ord. of 9-1-98, § I) Sec. 70-152. - Implementation. The exemption from taxation provided in section 70-151 above shall be implemented as follows: (1) For the tax year commencing on January 1, 1999, the exemption from taxation shall be an amount equal to 20 percent of the value of such tangible personal property described in section 70-151 above. (2) For the tax year commencing on January 1, 2000, the exemption from taxation shall be an amount equal to 40 percent of the value of such tangible personal property described in section 70-151 above. (3) For the tax year commencing on January 1, 2001, the exemption from taxation shall be an amount equal to 60 percent of the value of such tangible personal property described in section 70-151 above. (4) For the tax year commencing on January 1, 2002, the exemption from taxation shall be an amount equal to 100 percent of the value of such tangible personal property described in section 70-151 above. (Ord. of 9-1-98, § II) Sec. 70-153. - Application for tangible personal property inventory exemption. (a) Any person, firm, or corporation seeking an exemption from ad valorem taxation of the classes of tangible personal property provided in section 70-151 above shall file a written application and schedule of property with the board of tax assessors on forms to be furnished by the board of tax assessors. Such application shall be filed in the year in which the exemption from taxation is sought and no later than the date on which the board of tax assessors or tax commissioner close their books for the return of taxes. The application for tangible personal property inventory exemption shall provide for: (1) A schedule of the inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production which shall include all partially finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state; (2) A schedule of the inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods; (3) A schedule of the inventory of finished goods which on January 1 are stored in a warehouse, dock, or wharf, whether public or private, and which are destined for shipment outside the state and the inventory or finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside this state and which are stored for transshipment to a final destination outside this state. The information required by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2 to be contained in the official books and records of the warehouse, dock, or wharf where such property is being stored, which official books and records are required to be open to the inspection of the taxing authorities of this state and the county, shall not be required to be included as part of or to accompany the application for such exemption. (b) For purposes of this section the term "file properly" shall mean and include the timely filing of the application and complete schedule of the inventory for which the exemption is sought on or before the date the board of tax assessors closes its books for the return of taxes. (c) The failure to properly file the application and schedule shall constitute a waiver of the exemption on the part of the person, firm, or corporation failing to make the application for such exemption for that year as follows: (1) The failure to report any inventory for which such exemption is sought and the schedule provided for in the application shall constitute a waiver of the exemption on the part of the person, firm, or corporation failing to so report for that taxable year in an amount equal to the difference between the fair market value of the inventory as reported and the fair market value finally determined to be applicable to the inventory for which the exemption is sought. (2) The failure to file timely such application and schedule shall constitute a waiver of the exemption until the first day of the month following the month such application and schedule are filed properly with the tax assessor; provided, however, that unless the application and schedule are filed on or before June 1, of such year, the exemption shall be waived for that entire year. (d) Upon receiving the application and schedule, the board of tax assessors shall determine the eligibility of all types of tangible personal property listed on the application. If any property has been listed which the board of tax assessors believes is not eligible for the exemption, the board of tax assessors shall issue a letter notifying the applicant that all or a portion of the application has been denied. The denial letter shall list the type and total fair market value of all property listed on the application for which the exemption has been approved and the type and total fair market value of all property listed on the application for which the exemption has been denied. The applicant shall have the right to appeal from the denial of the exemption for any property listed and such appeal shall proceed as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-311. (Ord. of 9-1-98, § III) Secs. 70-154—70-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - OCCUPATION TAX
Sec. 70-171. - Purpose of ordinance and findings. (1) Purposes. The purposes of this article are to: (a) Protect the public health, safety and well being of the citizens of the county; (b) Collect and maintain information concerning the number, types and locations of businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations operating within the unincorporated areas of the county; (c) Classify and categorize businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations operating within the unincorporated areas of the county according to the number of employees employed by each; (d) Impose and collect an occupation tax on each business, profession, practitioner and occupation operating within the unincorporated areas of the county as authorized by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-6 et seq.; (e) Impose and collect a regulatory fee on certain businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations operating within the unincorporated areas of the county as authorized by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-8 et seq.; and (f) Provide for uniform rules, regulations, methods and exemptions for the collection and administration of the occupation tax and regulatory fees authorized hereunder. (2) Findings. In connection with the adoption of this article, it is hereby ascertained, determined and declared by the board that: (a) To ensure that the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the county are protected, information must be collected and maintained concerning the number, types and locations of businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations operating within the unincorporated areas of the county; (b) Uniform rules and regulations concerning the imposition, collection and administration of occupation taxes and regulatory fees are needed to carry out the purposes of this article; and (c) The board has determined that categorizing businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations operating within the unincorporated areas of the county based upon number of employees and collection and imposition [of] an occupation tax and/or regulatory fee based upon said categorization is the most efficient, economic and beneficial means to carry out the purposes of this article. (Ord. No. 09-006, § I, 7-7-09) Sec. 70-172. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. Board means the board of commissioners of Catoosa County, Georgia, or the governing authority of Catoosa County, Georgia, if other than a board of commissioners. Business includes, but is not necessarily limited to, an individual, practitioner, partnership, corporation or other entity engaged in an occupation, profession or other venture within the unincorporated areas of the county for the purpose of generating revenue. County means the County of Catoosa, a political subdivision of the State of Georgia. Employee shall have the definition and meaning described in the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5(1.1), which said provisions are expressly incorporated by reference herein. Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. Occupation tax means a tax levied on businesses, professions, practitioners, persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes within the unincorporated areas of the county. Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by the county as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the county. Any regulatory fee imposed by the county shall not include an administrative fee or registration fee. Any regulatory fees imposed by the county shall not be considered as or include development impact fees as defined by paragraph (8) of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development. (Ord. No. 09-006, § II, 7-7-09) Sec. 70-173. - Categorization of businesses. Pursuant to the authority granted by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10(a)(1), businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations which are subject to the provisions of this article are categorized on the basis of the number of employees employed by said business. The categories of each business, profession, practitioner and occupation by number of employees are more particularly set forth on Table 1.1 which is attached hereto and made a part hereof. (Ord. No. 09-006, § III, 7-7-09) Editor's note— The above-referenced Table 1.1 can be found in section 70-180 of this Code. Sec. 70-174. - Occupation tax provisions. (1) Businesses located within the county. Each and every business, practitioner, profession or occupation with a location or office lying solely within the unincorporated areas of the county shall be subject to and shall pay an occupation tax according to the number of full time or full time equivalent employees employed by the business, practitioner, profession or occupation. In order to establish the number of full time or full time equivalent employees, the county shall utilize the criteria set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10(a). The amount of the occupation tax imposed on each category of business, practitioner, profession or occupation shall be the amount described and shown on Table 1.1 which is attached hereto and made a part hereof. (2) Businesses located outside the county. Pursuant to the authority granted by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, each and every business, practitioner, profession or occupation which has no location or office within the boundaries of the county or the State of Georgia shall pay an occupation tax hereunder provided the business, practitioner, profession or occupation: (a) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the unincorporated areas of the county for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (b) Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located in the unincorporated areas of the county. The occupation tax imposed upon businesses, practitioners, professions or occupations pursuant to this section shall be based upon the number of employees and shall be in the amount described and shown on Table 1.1 which is attached hereto and made a part hereof. (3) Purpose and scope of occupational tax. The occupation tax imposed hereunder shall be applicable only to those businesses, practitioners, professions and occupations described and authorized by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 through O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. The occupation tax is imposed by the county for revenue purposes and not for regulatory purposes. The payment of the occupation tax imposed hereunder shall not be deemed as a condition precedent to the payment of any particular trade, profession or occupation. (4) Registration requirements. (a) Each and every business, profession, practitioner or occupation subject to payment of the occupation tax hereunder shall be required to obtain an annual registration and/or license from the county evidencing payment of the required tax. The registration shall be issued by the county manager or such other office of the county as may be designated by the board from time to time. (b) Prior to obtaining the required annual registration and paying the occupation tax, each business, profession, practitioner or occupation shall complete an application identifying the primary or dominant line of business being conducted and the number of employees employed by the business, profession, practitioner or occupation. If a business, profession, practitioner or occupation includes more than one line of business or is operated at more than one location or office, the number of employees employed at each location or office shall be entered on a separate application and the number of employees employed in each different line of business identified shall be disclosed and provided on the application. (c) Only employees of a business, profession, practitioner or occupation who actually work within the boundaries of the county shall be counted for occupation tax purposes. Upon request by the county, a business, profession, practitioner or occupation with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide information concerning the names and numbers of employees who work within and outside the county. (d) The required license/registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place if the business, profession, practitioner or occupation has a permanent location or office within the county. If the business, profession, practitioner or occupation does not have a permanent location or office within the county, said registration shall be displayed to the county manager or any county codes enforcement officer upon request. (5) Administrative fee. The occupation tax collected hereunder includes an administrative fee in order to offset the cost and expenses incurred by the county in administering this article and handling and processing the occupation tax collected hereunder. (6) Collection and payment of occupation tax. (a) The occupation tax due hereunder (including the necessary application for said tax) shall be paid each calendar year. The application shall be provided and occupation tax paid on an annual basis on January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by March 1 of each year. (b) Any new business, profession, practitioner or occupation commencing business in the county during a calendar year shall file the application and pay the full amount of the occupation tax within ten days of beginning to transact business within the county. Provided, however, if a business, profession, practitioner or occupation commences business in the county after July 1 of any given year, the amount of occupation tax due shall be 50 percent of the actual occupation tax amount for the calendar year in which business was commenced. However, any business, profession, practitioner or occupation commencing business after July 1 shall not receive a reduction in the administrative fee and any profession or practitioner electing to pay the occupation tax described in subsection (7) hereunder shall not receive a reduction in said tax if business is commenced after July 1 of any given calendar year. (7) Occupation tax for certain professions. All practitioners of those professions enumerated in the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18) shall make an election to pay the required occupation tax using either of the following criteria: (a) Based upon the number of full time and/or full time employees employed in the business, profession, practitioner or occupation as more particularly set forth on Table 1.1 which is attached hereto and made a part hereof; or (b) Based upon a fee/tax imposed per practitioner licensed to perform or provide the service provided by the business or profession. Said fee/tax shall be paid at the practitioner's location or office and said per-practitioner fee/tax applies to each person in the business or profession who qualifies as a practitioner under applicable state regulatory guidelines and laws. A practitioner electing to pay the fee/tax under this subsection shall not be required to furnish the county with information or documents concerning the gross receipts of the business or profession. The fee/tax paid pursuant to this subsection is set forth on Table 1.2 which is attached hereto and made a part hereof. The election required hereunder shall be made on an annual basis and must be made on or before January 1 of each calendar year. This subsection shall not apply to practitioners whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the government of the United States, State of Georgia, or any county or any municipality of the State of Georgia. Said individuals shall not be required to pay the occupational tax or file any applications required hereunder. (8) Multiple locations within the county. When a business, profession, practitioner or occupation conducts and/or transacts business at more than one fixed location or office within the unincorporated areas of the county, each location or office shall be considered a separate and distinct business, profession, practitioner or occupation for the purposes of payment of the occupation tax required hereunder. (9) State registration and licensure. (a) Any business, profession, practitioner or occupation which is required to be licensed by the Georgia Secretary of State pursuant to the provisions of Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated shall provide the county with evidence of the required state licensure prior to commencing business within the county and prior to paying the occupation tax required hereunder and being issued any registration by the county. (b) Any business, profession, practitioner or occupation required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or other regulatory permits, registrations qualifications or licenses shall provide the county with evidence that all qualifications are current and met prior to commencing business within the county and prior to paying the occupation tax required hereunder and being issued any registration by the county. (c) Each business, profession, practitioner or occupation required to maintain any license, permit, bond, certificate or registration referenced in this section shall conspicuously post the same at the location or office of the business, profession, practitioner or occupation and it shall continue to be posted as long as the license, permit, bond, certificate or registration remains valid. (Ord. No. 09-006, § IV, 7-7-09) Editor's note— The above-referenced Table 1.1 can be found in section 70-180 of this Code. Sec. 70-175. - Regulatory fee provisions. (1) Applicability. Pursuant to the authority granted in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-8(a), there is hereby imposed a regulatory fee upon the following categories of businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations transacting business within the unincorporated areas of the county: (a) Building and construction contractors, subcontractors, and workers; (b) Carnivals; (c) Taxicab and limousine operators; (d) Tattoo artists; (e) Stables; (f) Shooting galleries and firearm ranges; (g) Scrap metal processors; (h) Pawnbrokers; (i) Food service establishments; (j) Dealers in precious metals; (k) Firearms dealers; (l) Peddlers; (m) Parking lots; (n) Nursing and personal care homes; (o) Newspaper vending boxes; (p) Modeling agencies; (q) Massage parlors; (r) Landfills; (s) Auto and motorcycle racing; (t) Boarding houses; (u) Businesses which provide appearance bonds; (v) Boxing and wrestling promoters; (w) Hotels and motels; (x) Hypnotists; (y) Handwriting analysts; (z) Health clubs, gyms, and spas; (aa) Fortunetellers; (bb) Garbage collectors; (cc) Escort services; (dd) Burglar and fire alarm installers; (ee) Locksmiths; and (ff) Any type of business, profession, practitioner or occupation authorized under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(a) and (b). The county manager (or such other county officer as designated by the board from time to time) shall notify any business, profession, practitioner or occupation required to pay a regulatory fee. (2) Purpose and scope of regulatory fee. The regulatory fee collected pursuant to this section is collected from businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations for which the county customarily performs investigation or inspection in order to protect the public health, safety, or welfare of the citizens of the county or in the course of enforcing a state or local building, health, or safety code. The regulatory fee is not collected or used as a means of raising revenue for general purposes but is collected to offset the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the county. (3) Collection and payment of regulatory fees. (a) The regulatory fee required hereunder shall be due in the amount and according to the schedule set forth on Table 1.3 which is attached hereto and made a part hereof. No portion of the regulatory fee shall include a separate administration fee. (b) The regulatory fee due hereunder shall be paid each calendar year. The regulatory fee shall be paid on an annual basis on January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by March 1 of each year. (c) Any new business, profession, practitioner or occupation required to pay a regulatory fee and which commences business in the county during a calendar year shall pay the full amount of the regulatory fee within ten days of beginning to transact business within the county. (4) Multiple locations within the county. When a business, profession, practitioner or occupation conducts and/or transacts business at more than one fixed location or office within the unincorporated areas of the county, each location or office shall be considered a separate and distinct business, profession, practitioner or occupation for the purposes of payment of the regulatory fee required hereunder. (Ord. No. 09-006, § V, 7-7-09) Editor's note— The above-referenced Table 1.3 can be found in section 70-180 of this Code. Sec. 70-176. - Exemptions. (1) General exemptions. The following businesses, professions, practitioners and occupations are exempt from payment of the occupation tax and regulatory fees required by this article: (a) Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission; (b) Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; (c) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agribusiness; (d) Any disabled veteran of any war or armed conflict in which any branch of the armed forces of the United States engaged, whether under United States command or otherwise; (e) Any blind person; (f) Any veteran of peace-time service in the United States armed forces who has a physical disability incurred during the period of such service; (g) Practitioners whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the government of the United States, State of Georgia, or any county or any municipality of the State of Georgia; (h) Any business operated solely for a charitable purpose. Provided, however, to qualify for said exemption a business must devote at least 50 percent of its gross receipts to charitable purposes and must furnish the county with written documentation confirming that at least 50 percent of its gross receipts were devoted to charitable purposes; (i) Cooperative marketing associations governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105; (j) Insurance companies governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq.; (k) Motor common carriers governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15; (l) Those businesses described in and governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355; (m) Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356; (n) Depository financial institutions governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93; (o) Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55; and (p) Any business, profession, practitioner or occupation upon which levy of an occupation tax or regulatory fee is prohibited by state or federal law. (2) Exemption applicable to small businesses. Pursuant to the authority contained in the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10(f), and in order to promote and encourage economic development and to further encourage, attract, develop and maintain small businesses within the county, including providing jobs and economic livelihood for many, all small businesses of whatever kind and nature located within the unincorporated areas of the county are exempt from paying the occupation tax imposed by this article. As utilized herein, the term "small business" shall be defined as a business or occupation which employs five or less employees. However, the term "small business" shall not include those professions or occupations listed on Table 1.2 hereof, regardless of the number of employees. (3) Exemption applicable to real estate brokers. Pursuant to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-17(a), no occupation tax shall be levied upon or collected from real estate brokers or agents who transact business within the county but whose offices are located outside the county. In the event the real estate agent or broker has a location or office within the county, he/she shall be subject to the occupation tax imposed hereunder. (Ord. No. 09-006, § VI, 7-7-09) Editor's note— The above-referenced Table 1.2 can be found in section 70-180 of this Code. Sec. 70-177. - Penalties and enforcement. (1) Inspection of books and records. All businesses, professions, practitioners or occupations subject to the requirements of this article shall keep and maintain current business records concerning the operations of said business. The county manager, through his officers, agents, employees and representatives, may inspect the books or records of any business, profession, practitioner or occupation which is subject to the requirements of this article and said books or records shall be submitted for inspection within 30 days of the date a request for inspection is made. Any records, books or information provided to or reviewed by the county shall, pursuant to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-15 and shall not be subject to disclosure under the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. (2) Delinquent penalties. In the event any occupation tax, administrative fee or regulatory fee remains unpaid for a period of 90 days after its due date, a delinquent penalty equal to ten percent of the occupation tax, administrative fee or regulatory fee shall be due and payable. In addition, interest shall accrue on unpaid occupation taxes, administrative fees or regulatory fees at the rate of one and one-half percent per month until paid. (3) Enforcement. In addition to all civil and criminal remedies authorized by this article, the Code of Catoosa County and Georgia Law, the officer charged with the collection of the occupation tax, administrative fee or regulatory fee hereunder shall be permitted to issue executions against any business, profession, practitioner or occupation for the amounts authorized by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. In addition, a civil fine may be imposed by a court of competent jurisdiction in an amount up to the maximum permitted by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. (4) Transaction of business. No business, profession, practitioner or occupation shall transact business or collect fees or monies from the transaction of business in the county unless and until all requirements of the ordinance are met and all occupation taxes, administrative fees and regulatory fees are paid current. Any business, profession, practitioner or occupation (which includes the person or persons soliciting for or representing said entities) which transacts business in the county in violation of this article or while any fees or taxes due hereunder are delinquent shall be subject to any and all remedies and penalties available under this article, the Code of Catoosa County or Georgia law. (Ord. No. 09-006, § VIII, 7-7-09) Sec. 70-178. - Court proceedings. (1) Jurisdiction. Violations of this article shall be tried in the magistrate court of the county. (2) Available remedies. Nothing in this section shall prevent the county from bringing any civil action for injunction, mandamus or other proceedings to present, correct or abate any violation of this article. No sanction, penalty or remedy described herein shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other sanction, penalty or remedy at equity or law. (3) Separate violations. Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (4) Public records. Records of convictions for violation of this article shall be a matter of public record. (5) Bench warrants. No person accused of violating this ordinance shall be arrested prior to trial, but any defendant who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and required to post a bond for his future appearances. (Ord. No. 09-006, § VIII, 7-7-09) Sec. 70-179. - General provisions. (1) Public hearings. A public hearing shall be held by the board prior to any increase in the occupation tax, administrative fee or regulatory fee due hereunder.
